content: Chris, it’s great to see some sort of measurement going on in real, actual call conversations with sales reps. As someone who wakes up everyday to work to see more women in sales and sales leadership roles in companies that are traditionally male-majority on their sales teams — I’m not interested in who’s better because there is room for both great women and great men in sales. The issue for me is, “how do we find better sellers — regardless of who they are.” What the stats don’t show is what sorts of onboarding programs these reps who made the 32K calls participated in. With a number of companies involved, even if “similar” the onboarding, training, and coaching will vary greatly. Even within a company with a good program, sometimes due to headcount (or lack of it) new reps can come on and “jump in” with little support. With that said, I can certainly tout the results of your research when I talk to young women who have not considered a sales career or who might be thinking of changing from one team within their company to sales. Even though the end result (more sales) is on the women’s side for this study, it is not exhaustive and is not qualitative — What it is though, is the first study of its kind that I have seen and should encourage more research into what makes reps great — no matter who they are.
